42.title: Passivation Mechanism Exploiting Surface Dipoles Affords High-Performance Perovskite Solar Cells
42.journal: Journal of the American Chemical Society
42.abstract: The employment of 2D perovskites is a promising approach to tackling the stability and voltage issues inherent in perovskite solar cells. Here, we report the use of quasi-3D azetidinium lead iodide (AzPbI3) as a secondary layer on top of the primary 3D perovskite film that results in significant improvements in the photovoltaic parameters.

introduction.text: High-performance perovskite solar cells (PSCs) with efficiencies exceeding 20% hold considerable promise in photoelectric energy conversion.

conclusions.text: We hereby demonstrate a means of fabricating efficient and stable perovskite solar cells by employing Azetidinium lead iodide as a dual passivating and protecting layer.

paper.title: Temporal and spatial pinhole constraints in small-molecule hole transport layers for stable and efficient perovskite photovoltaics

steps: Thermal evaporation of the Au electrode

45.title: Working principle of carrier selective poly-Si/c-Si junctions: Is tunnelling the whole story?
45.abstract: We present arguments that additional effects besides laterally homogeneous tunnelling might occur in carrier-selective poly-Si/c-Si junctions: (i) the symmetrical electrical behaviour of n þ and p þ poly-Si/c-Si junctions, (ii) direct observation of structural modifications of the interfacial oxide upon thermal treatment by transmission electron microscopy, even for poly-Si/c-Si junctions with good passivation quality, and (iii) the achievement of low junction resistances even for interfacial oxide thicknesses 42 nm after thermal treatment.
45.model: Localized current flow through pinholes or regions with locally reduced interfacial oxide thickness

39.title: 2D/3D perovskite engineering eliminates interfacial recombination losses in hybrid perovskite solar cells

introduction.text: Understanding interface energetics and physics is essential for gaining fundamental knowledge of perovskite solar cells' operation and optimization. 2D/ 3D perovskite interfaces incorporating thiophene-based bulky organic cations are investigated. By fine tuning the halide counterion of the thiophene-based cation, a p-n junction is formed at the interface. The formation of a p-n junction eliminates the interfacial recombination losses by reducing the electron density, resulting in devices with high V OC, which approach the potential internal quasi-Fermi level splitting of the perovskite absorber.

results_and_discussion.text: The 2D/3D interfaces investigated here are based on a novel set of bulky thiopheneterminated cations, namely, 2-thiophenemethylammonium iodide (2-TMAI), 9,26 2-thiophenemethylammonium bromide (2-TMABr), and 2-thiophenemethylammonium chloride (2-TMACl) that serve as a building block for the formation of the 2D perovskite layer on top of the 3D bulk layer (Figure 1A).

methods.text: The 3D perovskite layer was deposited by spin coating the precursor solution at 2,000 rpm for 12 s and 5,000 rpm for 30 s. Chlorobenzene was poured on top of the spinning substrate 15 s prior to the end of the spin-coating process. The deposited 3D perovskite film was annealed at 100 C for 60 min.

photovoltaic_characterization.text: The current density-voltage (J-V) curves were measured under 1 sun illumination (AM 1.5G) in the ambient atmosphere and temperature using xenon lamp solar simulator (450 W, Oriel, AAA class).

stability_test.text: The long-term stability of the devices was monitored under continuous illumination of 1-sun intensity for 1,000 h in an argon atmosphere.

85.perovskite_composition: FAPbI3 x 95%, MAPbBr3 x 3%, HTAB x 1%

14.title: 23.7% Efficient Inverted Perovskite Solar Cells by Dual Interfacial Modification

introduction.text: Metal halide perovskites have experienced a rapid progress in highimpact optoelectronics, with particularly notable advances made in the field of perovskite photovoltaics.

dual_interfacial_modification_approach.description: Dual interfacial modification approach by integrating large organic cations at both the electron and HTL interfaces.

66.title: Optimization of Perovskite Solar Cells: Encapsulation and Outdoor Testing
66.abstract: This paper presents two complementary encapsulation strategies for perovskite solar cells: glue-based encapsulation (LAB) and lamination-based encapsulation (COM). The LAB method uses a UV-curable adhesive and a flat coverslip, while the COM method uses a butyl rubber edge seal and a polyolefin film. The performance of both encapsulation methods is evaluated through on-shelf stability testing, damp heat testing, and outdoor exposure experiments.

methods.title: Solar Cell Fabrication
methods.description: Perovskite solar cells with p-i-n structure fabricated on ITO substrates

methods.title: Encapsulation
methods.description: LAB and COM encapsulation methods

methods.title: Stability Testing
methods.description: On-shelf stability testing, damp heat testing, and outdoor exposure experiments

results.title: On-Shelf Stability
results.description: Cells with LAB encapsulation retain >93% of efficiency after 1566 h on-shelf

results.title: Damp Heat Testing
results.description: LAB encapsulation allows cell to retain >98% of efficiency after 8 h of damp heat exposure

results.title: Outdoor Exposure
results.description: LAB encapsulation lasts up to 3 months, while COM encapsulation lasts >6 months

conclusions.title: Comparison of Encapsulation Methods
conclusions.description: LAB and COM encapsulation methods have different performance characteristics

conclusions.title: Recommendations
conclusions.description: Suitable encapsulation strategy for samples shipping and short-term test

64.title: Vacuum-Deposited 2D/3D Perovskite Heterojunctions
64.abstract: We report the fabrication of 2D/3D perovskite heterojunctions by dual-source vacuum deposition, with the aim of studying the interaction between the 3D and 2D phases as well as the charge transport properties of 2D perovskites in neat 2D/3D interfaces.

64.discussion: The results show that the 2D/3D perovskite heterojunctions exhibit a trade-off between the open-circuit voltage and fill factor, with 3D/2D heterojunction solar cells having open-circuit voltage as high as 1.1 V.
64.conclusion: The study demonstrates the potential of vacuum-deposited 2D/3D perovskite heterojunctions for solar cells, but highlights the need for further research to improve the charge transport properties and device stability.

7.text: The 2D Halide Perovskite Rulebook: How the Spacer Influences Everything from the Structure to Optoelectronic Device Efficiency

134.title: Guanabenz acetate salt enhances the stability of perovskite solar cells in ambient air
134.abstract: We report the fabrication of high-efficiency perovskite solar cells in ambient air by blocking hydration using guanabenz acetate salt. The incorporation of GBA eliminates both cation and anion vacancies, blocking the perovskite hydration and allowing the crystallization of a high-quality film in ambient air. The resulting PSCs exhibit a power conversion efficiency of 25.32% and maintain 96% of their initial efficiency after 500 hours of operating at the maximum power point under simulated AM 1.5 G solar light.
device_fabrication: Preparation of the FTO glass substrate
Preparation of the compact TiO2 electron transport layer
Preparation of perovskite via the two-step method with different humidities
Preparation of perovskite by the one-step method
Preparation of the Spiro-OMeTAD hole transport layer
results: Photovoltaic performance of control and target PSCs
Photovoltaic parameters for target and control champion PSCs
Photovoltaic parameters for target and control champion PSCs fabricated in ambient air by one-step
Photovoltaic parameters for target and control champion PSCs fabricated in ambient air by one-step
The parameters of α-FAPbI3 structure in DFT
The parameters of α-FAPbI3 structure in DFT
134.discussion: The incorporation of GBA eliminates both cation and anion vacancies, blocking the perovskite hydration and allowing the crystallization of a high-quality film in ambient air. The resulting PSCs exhibit a power conversion efficiency of 25.32% and maintain 96% of their initial efficiency after 500 hours of operating at the maximum power point under simulated AM 1.5 G solar light.
134.conclusion: The incorporation of GBA enhances the stability of perovskite solar cells in ambient air, making it a promising approach for the fabrication of high-performance PSCs in a scalable and industrialized fashion.

72.title: Suppressed Ion Migration in Reduced-Dimensional Perovskites Improves Operating Stability
72.abstract: Impressive progress in halide perovskite solar cells motivates further work to improve operating stability. We find that quasi-two-dimensional (2.5D) perovskites suppress ion-migration-driven decomposition. Using TOF-SIMS, we confirm that iodide migration occurs in bulk perovskite photovoltaic devices operating at their maximum power point (MPP). We observe that iodine ions migrate across the spiro-OMeTAD layer to the spiro-gold contact interface, oxidizing and deteriorating the gold at the interface. In contrast, we find that large ⟨n⟩ 2.5D perovskites exhibit a significantly reduced rate of ion migration compared to 3D devices and exhibit less than 1% relative PCE loss in over 80 h of continuous operation at MPP, whereas the PCE of 3D devices diminishes by more than 50% within the first 24 h.

methods.name: TOF-SIMS
methods.description: Time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy

methods.name: XRD
methods.description: X-ray diffraction

methods.name: PL
methods.description: Photoluminescence

methods.name: TRPL
methods.description: Time-resolved photoluminescence

methods.name: sputtering XPS
methods.description: Sputtering X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy

results.name: iodide ions are the dominant migrating species
results.description: Iodide ions migrate through the spiro layer and reach the spiro-gold interface, forming an iodine-gold complex

results.name: 2.5D perovskites exhibit improved operating stability
results.description: 2.5D perovskites have less than 1% relative PCE loss in over 80 h of continuous operation at MPP, whereas 3D devices diminish by more than 50% within the first 24 h

results.name: iodine migration is suppressed in 2.5D perovskites
results.description: Iodine migration is significantly reduced in 2.5D perovskites compared to 3D devices

conclusions.name: 2.5D perovskites are a promising material for improving operating stability in perovskite solar cells
conclusions.description: The use of 2.5D perovskites can help to reduce ion migration and improve the long-term performance of perovskite solar cells

123.title: Constructing heterojunctions by surface sulfidation for efficient inverted perovskite solar cells
123.text: A stable perovskite heterojunction was constructed for inverted solar cells through surface sulfidation of lead (Pb)-rich perovskite films. The formed lead-sulfur (Pb-S) bonds upshifted the Fermi level at the perovskite interface and induced an extra back-surface field for electron extraction. The resulting inverted devices exhibited a power conversion efficiency (PCE) >24% with a high open-circuit voltage of 1.19 volts, corresponding to a low voltage loss of 0.36 volts. The strong Pb-S bonds could stabilize perovskite heterojunctions and strengthen underlying perovskite structures that have a similar crystal lattice. Devices with surface sulfidation retained more than 90% of the initial PCE after aging at 85°C for 2200 hours or operating at the maximum power point under continuous illumination for 1000 hours at 55°± 5°C.
